{{Use Australian English|date=August 2011}} {{Use dmy dates|date=March 2011}} [[File:2008 02 10 Xenu is not impressed.jpg|thumb|A protester, dressed as the Scientology god [[Xenu]], stands next to a Scientology building in [[Sydney, Australia]] (2008)]] '''[[Scientology]]''' has existed in '''Australia''' since the early 1950s. The number of adherents varies depending upon the source: according to the 2011 census, it has a declining population, 2,163 members, down from 2,507 in 2006,{{cite web|last=Cannane|first=Steve|title=Census shows scientology numbers going backwards|url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2012-06-29/scientology-numbers-going-backwards/4101958| date=30 June 2012 |website=ABC News|accessdate=30 June 2012|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120630023551/http://www.abc.net.au/news/2012-06-29/scientology-numbers-going-backwards/4101958 |archivedate=30 June 2012 |deadurl=no}} while Scientology itself has claimed 150,000 members in Australia.{{cite news |author=Casey, Marcus |title=Sales Pitch for the Souls |work=[[The Daily Telegraph (Sydney)|The Daily Telegraph]] |page=32 |date=19 April 1997}}{{cite news |author=Powell, Sian |title=Church's Quiet Spread |work=The Weekend Australian |date=1 Feb 1997}} The 2016 census records 1,684 people describing their religion as Scientology.{{Cite web|url=https://guest.censusdata.abs.gov.au/webapi/jsf/login.xhtml|title=Census TableBuilder - Guest Users Log in|website=guest.censusdata.abs.gov.au|language=en|access-date=2017-08-12}} It has headquarters in [[Sydney]], [[Melbourne]], [[Perth]], [[Adelaide]], and [[Canberra]], along with a [[Scientology Missions International|mission]] in Tasmania. The Church of Scientology Australia is the regional headquarters for the entire Asian and Pacific area.{{cite news| url=http://au.news.yahoo.com/a/-/newshome/7381845/scientology-part-5-dummies-guide-to-religion/ | work=Yahoo!7 | title=Scientology: Part 5 – Dummies guide to religion | date=11 June 2010 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131204043416/http://au.news.yahoo.com/a/7381845/scientology-part-5-dummies-guide-to-religion/ |archivedate=4 December 2013 |deadurl=no}} ==Beginnings== As early as 1950, [[Dianetics]] was mentioned in Australia as "the latest craze in Hollywood"{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article18483835 |title=Hollywood has a cure-all |newspaper=[[The Sunday Herald (Sydney)|The Sunday Herald]] |location=Sydney |date=1 October 1950 |accessdate=13 August 2013 |page=12 Supplement: Sunday Herald Features |publisher=National Library of Australia}} and the "Hubbard sub-mind method" was explained under the heading "World of Science".{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article42664974 |title=Sub-mind recordings |newspaper=[[The Cairns Post]] |author=Blakeslee, Harold W. |location=Qld. |date=22 April 1950 |accessdate=13 August 2013 |page=4 |publisher=National Library of Australia}} However, this also meant Hubbard, founder of the Dianetics Mental Health movement, was also newsworthy when his wife claimed he was 'hopelessly insane' in their divorce case and this was reported in several major papers.{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article27017179 |title=Says Mental Expert Husband Insane |newspaper=[[The Mercury (Hobart)|The Mercury]] |location=Hobart, Tas. |date=25 April 1951 |accessdate=13 August 2013 |page=3 |publisher=National Library of Australia}}{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article50105365 |title=Sanity "Expert" Mad, Claims Wife |newspaper=[[The Courier-Mail]] |location=Brisbane |date=25 April 1951 |accessdate=13 August 2013 |page=1 |publisher=National Library of Australia}}{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article45704449 |title=Wife Says Mental Expert "Hopelessly Insane" |newspaper=[[The Advertiser (Adelaide)|The Advertiser]] |location=Adelaide |date=25 April 1951 |accessdate=13 August 2013 |page=3 |publisher=National Library of Australia}} By the early 1950s, advertisements mentioning Scientology began to appear in newspapers. Scientology Associates (Mental Health) offered "professional psycho-therapeutic treatments"{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article23244044 |title=Advertising |newspaper=[[The Argus (Melbourne)|The Argus]] |location=Melbourne |date=13 May 1953 |accessdate=13 August 2013 |page=2 |publisher=National Library of Australia}} while for "Rev. John R. Farrell, Church of Scientology" it was "Personal Relations. – I will talk to anyone for you about anything".{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article71788991 |title=Advertising |newspaper=[[The Argus (Melbourne)|The Argus]] |location=Melbourne |date=29 December 1955 |accessdate=13 August 2013 |page=13 |publisher=National Library of Australia}} And in April 1954 the [[Hubbard Association of Scientologists International]] held the First Australian Scientology Congress in [[Prahran, Victoria]], over four days, featuring "American Lecturers, John and Tuck Farrell, and English lecturer, Raymond Kemp, all Doctors of Scientology".{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article65383944 |title=Advertising |newspaper=[[Healesville Guardian]] |location=Lilydale, Vic. |date=18 March 1955 |accessdate=13 August 2013 |page=3 |publisher=National Library of Australia}} In 1959, L. Ron Hubbard travelled to Australia and delivered lectures on 7 to 8 November at the Melbourne Congress and the First Melbourne Advanced Clinical Course from 9 to 30 November.{{cite book |author=Hubbard, L. Ron |date=1976 |title=The Technical Bulletins of Dianetics and Scientology. Volume III |pages=542–546 |publisher=Bridge Publications (Los Angeles) |isbn=0-88404-043-7}} ==Interaction with education== Through its group [[Citizens Commission on Human Rights]], Scientology is active in the media about what it claims are the dangers of psychiatric drugs and the treatment of ADHD and has arranged at least one anti-psychiatry exhibition in Australia. That exhibition, which opened in [[Sydney]] in September 2006, was criticised by [[Christopher Pyne]], then the federal government's parliamentary secretary for health with special responsibilities for mental health. Pyne told ''[[The Daily Telegraph (Sydney)|The Daily Telegraph]]'':
"It's incredibly irresponsible....What if a patient, after seeing this exhibition, decided to stop seeing a psychiatrist? The outcome could be tragic... It's ill-informed and it's dangerous to undermine a highly respected and important part of the medical profession... Patients who see a psychiatrist shouldn't have their faith in psychiatry shaken by crackpot claims."{{cite news |title=MP: No science in Scientology |newspaper=[[The Daily Telegraph (Sydney)|The Daily Telegraph]] |location=NSW |date=14 September 2006}}
In response, Shelly Wilkins, executive director of the exhibition "said the campaign was not against psychiatrists, but their treatments". Scientology, through its group [[Narconon]], has run an anti-drug campaign in dozens of schools in Melbourne, giving presentations and handing out brochures.{{cite news |author=Houlihan, Liam |newspaper=Herald Sun |title=Scientology Lessons |page=15 |date=16 August 2005}} Scientology members have also attended events like the [[Big Day Out]] to give out anti-drug information. One school in Australia, the [[Athena School]] in [[Newtown, New South Wales|Newtown]], Sydney, uses Scientology study technology. The Athena School has 90 pupils ranging from pre-school to year 10. It has eight teachers who have completed six months' training in L. Ron Hubbard teaching techniques but do not hold formal qualifications.{{cite web |url=http://www.smh.com.au/articles/2003/06/23/1056220542333.html |author=Burke, Kelly. |title=Scientology class suits shy Hindu |work=Sydney Morning Herald |date=4 July 2003 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121023030543/http://www.smh.com.au/articles/2003/06/23/1056220542333.html |archivedate=23 October 2012 |deadurl=no}} Some children at the school are involved in Scientology community out reach programs operating under different names, including Drug Free Ambassadors.{{cite web |url=http://www.athena.nsw.edu.au/ethics-and-morals/ |title=Ethics and Morals, Community Work |publisher=The Athens School |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140204015221/http://www.athena.nsw.edu.au/ethics-and-morals/ |archivedate=4 February 2014 |deadurl=no}} == Banning of ''Tom Cruise: An Unauthorized Biography'' by Australian book retailers == A book released detailing Tom Cruise's activities within Scientology was banned by the major Australian booksellers in Australia, including [[Dymocks]] and [[Angus and Robertson]], after threats of legal action by the Church of Scientology. The book, ''[[Tom Cruise: An Unauthorized Biography]]'' by British writer [[Andrew Morton (writer)|Andrew Morton]], had been pulled from sale in the UK, and made a number of claims against Cruise and claims about Scientology trying to influence [[Nicole Kidman]].{{cite news| url=http://www.theage.com.au/articles/2008/01/12/1199988647992.html | location=Melbourne | work=The Age | title=Scientology holds sway in banning Cruise book | date=13 January 2008 | first=Angela | last=Cuming |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121104100829/http://www.theage.com.au/articles/2008/01/12/1199988647992.html |archivedate=4 November 2012 |deadurl=no}}{{cite news| first=Bryan |last=Seymour |url=http://au.todaytonight.yahoo.com/article/129542 | work=Yahoo!7 | title=Book battle: Scientology and Tom Cruise| date=15 January 2008 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080212022950/http://au.todaytonight.yahoo.com/article/129542 |archivedate=12 February 2008 |deadurl=yes}} The Australian arm of publisher [[Pan Macmillan]] had planned to print a local Australian edition, but decided not to, after legal advice that the Church would act against them.{{cite web |url=http://www.smh.com.au/news/books/publisher-dumps-tom-cruise-book/2008/01/15/1200159419934.html?page=fullpage#contentSwap1 |author=Tadros, Edmund |title=Publisher dumps Tom Cruise book|work=Sydney Morning Herald |date=15 January 2008 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080124002939/http://www.smh.com.au/news/books/publisher-dumps-tom-cruise-book/2008/01/15/1200159419934.html?page=fullpage#contentSwap1 |archivedate=24 January 2008 |deadurl=no}} This resulted in the book not being stocked by the Borders chain in Australia. Though certain bookstores in Australia refused to sell the book due to legal concerns, it was the number one bestseller in Australia for publisher [[AbeBooks]] in 2008,{{cite news | last =[[AbeBooks]] | title =2008: A Year of Books in Review | work =Bookseller Digest UK | publisher =booksellerdigest.abebooks.co.uk | date =12 January 2009 | url =http://booksellerdigest.abebooks.co.uk/2009/01/2008-a-year-of-books-in-review-.html | accessdate = 27 March 2009 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090423133938/http://booksellerdigest.abebooks.co.uk/2009/01/2008-a-year-of-books-in-review-.html |archivedate=23 April 2009 |deadurl=no}} and the number one most-borrowed non-fiction book at libraries in [[Brisbane]] in September 2008.{{cite news | last =The Courier-Mail staff | title =Top 10 books | work =[[The Courier-Mail]] | page =M25 | date =6 September 2008}} ''Tom Cruise: An Unauthorized Biography'' was published in January 2008, and reprinted with an update in February 2009. In a ''[[New York Times]]'' review, Janet Maslin wrote "... Mr. Morton has found a number of former Scientologists who are willing to speak freely, and in some cases vengefully, about the group's purported inner workings. Mr. Morton's eagerness to include their voices leads him to push the limits of responsible reporting." Maslin added that Morton "provides a credible portrait extrapolated from the actor's on-the-record remarks and highly visible public behavior."{{cite news | last =Maslin | first =Janet | title =Tom Cruise and His Bully Pulpit | work =[[The New York Times]] | pages = | date =10 January 2008 | url =https://www.nytimes.com/2008/01/10/books/10masl.html | accessdate =18 January 2008|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120705014648/http://www.nytimes.com/2008/01/10/books/10masl.html |archivedate=5 July 2012 |deadurl=no}} Writing in ''[[Entertainment Weekly]]'', [[Mark Harris (journalist)|Mark Harris]] gave the book a grade of "C-", and said "Cruise emerges from Morton's takedown moderately scratched but as uncracked as ever."{{cite news | last =Harris | first =Mark | coauthors = | title =Review: New Cruise biography comes up empty | work =[[Entertainment Weekly]] | pages = | language = | publisher =[[CNN|CNN.com]] | date =9 January 2008 | url =http://www.cnn.com/2008/SHOWBIZ/books/01/09/review.cruise/index.html | accessdate = 18 January 2008 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080123132502/http://www.cnn.com/2008/SHOWBIZ/books/01/09/review.cruise/index.html |archivedate=23 January 2008 |deadurl=no}} Another review in the ''New York Times'' by Ada Calhooun said:{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2008/02/17/books/review/Calhoun-t.html |title=Scientology's Star |date=17 February 2008 |work =[[The New York Times]] |author=Calhoun, Ada |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20130803163854/http://www.nytimes.com/2008/02/17/books/review/Calhoun-t.html |archivedate=3 August 2013 |deadurl=no}} :''However shady Scientology may be, Morton's language in "Tom Cruise: An Unauthorized Biography" is extreme. He and his sources compare the church and its leadership to fascists, the Roman Empire, storm troopers, Machiavelli, Orwell's "Animal Farm," Napoleon, Stalinists and North Korea. He also repeatedly invokes Nazism, and quotes without censure the German Protestant Church's comparison of Cruise to Joseph Goebbels.'' Teresa Budasi of the ''[[Chicago Sun-Times]]'' described the book as "fascinating", although Budasi also brought up a "question as to what's true and what isn’t."{{cite news|last=Budasi |first=Teresa |coauthors= |title=Review: Cruise bio describes his best role: Scientologist – Focus on 'cult' doesn't make movie star more interesting |work=[[Chicago Tribune]] |pages= |language= |publisher= |date=17 January 2008 |url=http://www.suntimes.com/entertainment/books/746071,tomrev011708.article |accessdate=18 January 2008 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070814032746/http://www.suntimes.com/entertainment/books/746071%2Ctomrev011708.article |archivedate=14 August 2007 |deadurl=yes |df= }} Budasi summed up her impression of the work, writing "Morton's book is as much an indictment on Cruise's chosen faith as it is the life story of one of the world's biggest movie stars. And by the end you realize that 'Scientologist' is what will end up being the role of his lifetime." In a review in ''[[The Buffalo News]]'', Jeff Simon wrote of the author: "To give Morton the credit he's clearly due: he is one of the best around at constructing a 250-page gossip column."{{cite news | last =Simon | first =Jeff | coauthors = | title =A dangerous man, or a falling star? | work =[[The Buffalo News]] | pages = | language = | publisher = | date =19 January 2008 | url =http://www.buffalonews.com/185/story/255378.html | accessdate = 2008-01-19 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20080122111327/http://www.buffalonews.com/185/story/255378.html |archivedate = 22 January 2008 |deadurl=yes}} Upon its publication, Cruise's lawyer and the [[Church of Scientology]] released statements which question the truthfulness of assertions made by Morton in the book. In a 15-page statement released to the press, the Church of Scientology called the book "a bigoted, defamatory assault replete with lies."{{cite news | last = [[Associated Press]] | first = | coauthors = | title = Author of Cruise bio defends book | work = [[CNN]] | pages = | language = | publisher = [[Time Warner]] | date =16 January 2008 | url =http://www.cnn.com/2008/SHOWBIZ/books/01/16/people.tomcruise.ap/ | accessdate =18 January 2008 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20080119141931/http://www.cnn.com/2008/SHOWBIZ/books/01/16/people.tomcruise.ap/ |archivedate = 2008-01-19}} The book was not published in the UK, Australia, or New Zealand due to strict libel laws in those countries.{{cite web |url=http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/21134540/vp/22664012#22664012 |title=msnbc.com Video Player |accessdate=18 January 2008 |date=15 January 2007|format=video |work=[[MSNBC]]}} ==Banning and legal status== {{See also|Scientology status by country}} Government criticism of the Church of Scientology was begun by a [[Victoria, Australia|Victorian]] [[civil service|public servant]], Dr [[Eric Cunningham Dax]],{{cite book |author=Garrison, Omar V. |date=1974 |title=The Hidden Story of Scientology |publisher=Citadel Press |location=Secaucus NJ |ISBN=0-8065-0440-4 |page=145}} the founding Chairman of the Mental Hygiene Authority of [[Victoria, Australia|Victoria]] (later known as the Mental Health Authority). Giving testimony at the [[Anderson Report]] inquiry in 1964 he stated that 'Since 1961 he had been increasingly concerned by information reaching the Mental Health Authority about people paying large sums of money for "Scientology" courses'.{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article104295203 |title='Scientology' Perverted Inquiry Told |newspaper=[[The Canberra Times]] |date=28 May 1964 |accessdate=13 August 2013 |page=27 |publisher=National Library of Australia}} As part of these efforts, in 1962, Dax wrote to the Minister of Health in each Australian state, warning of what he considered to be the dangers of this new religion. In November 1963 [[John Galbally]], member of the [[Victorian Legislative Council]] 'accused the scientology movement of using blackmail and intimidation' which he said 'could lead to suicides'.{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article104289141 |title=Inquiry on Group Promised |newspaper=[[The Canberra Times]] |date=26 November 1963 |accessdate=13 August 2013 |page=8 |publisher=National Library of Australia}} Galbally proposed 'a Private Member's Bill to deal with scientology' and the following week the government announced a proposed inquiry. ===1965 Victorian Board of Inquiry into Scientology=== {{See also|Anderson Report}} Based on the findings of the 1965 [[Anderson Report|Anderson Inquiry]],{{cite web |url=http://www.cs.cmu.edu/~dst/Library/Shelf/anderson/index.html |title=Report of the Board of Enquiry into Scientology |author=Anderson, Kevin Victor, Q.C.|date=1965 |publisher=State of Victoria, Australia |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140209142835/http://www.cs.cmu.edu/~dst/Library/Shelf/anderson/index.html |archivedate=9 February 2014 |deadurl=no}} to which Dax contributed,{{cite book | author=Victoria. Board of Inquiry into Scientology |date=1963–64 |title=Transcript, Board of Inquiry into Scientology |pages=2976, 3207}} the Church of Scientology was restricted from forming under that name in Australia. The Attorney General in [[New South Wales]] was one of the first to act and, a week after the report was published, instructed the state's Registrar of Companies 'not to register companies or firms with the word "scientology" in their names'.{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article105867585 |title=Direction on Scientology |newspaper=[[The Canberra Times]] |date=16 October 1965 |accessdate=13 August 2013 |page=3 |publisher=National Library of Australia}} The ban in Victoria lasted from 1965 until 1973, in [[South Australia]] from 1968 to 1973 and in [[Western Australia]] from 1968 until 1972. As a response to the banning of Scientology in WA and SA, Scientology changed its name to the [[Church of the New Faith]], a body incorporated in [[Adelaide]] in 1969, and continued to operate in those two states. However, it closed its Spring St office in Melbourne, Victoria. The magistrates in the 1983 Victorian Court actions (see below) referenced the Anderson Inquiry, particularly that it was "Uncompromising in its denunciation of Scientology as a profoundly evil movement from which gullible – and the not so gullible – members of the community required protection", that it had "gained publicity in countries and states where the organization was entrenched"; that the leaders of the Scientology movement succumbed to the temptation to avoid "destruction" of the movement by simulating, so as to become accepted as, a religion; that "the ecclesiastical appearance now assumed by the organization is no more than colourable in order to serve an ulterior purpose"; and, ultimately, that Scientology
"... is, in relation to its religious pretensions, no more than a sham. The bogus claims to belief in the [[efficacy of prayer]] and to being adherent to a creed divinely inspired and also the calculated adoption of the paraphernalia, and participation in ceremonies, of conventional religion are no more than a mockery of religion. Thus scientology as now practiced is in reality the antithesis of a religion. The very adriotness – and alacrity – with which the tenets or structure were from time so cynically adapted to meet a deficiency thought to operate in detraction of the claim to classification as a religion serve to rob the movement of that sincerity and integrity that must be cardinal features of any religious faith".Victorian Supreme Court Judgement (1983) 1 VR, at pp 108-109. (at p170)
Anderson's tone was strident, but offered in his own defence:
If there should be detected in this Report a note of unrelieved denunciation of scientology, it is because the evidence has shown its theories to be fantastic and impossible, its principles perverted and ill-founded, and its techniques debased and harmful. [...] While making an appeal to the public as a worthy system whereby ability, intelligence and personality may be improved, it employs techniques which further its real purpose of securing domination over and mental enslavement of its adherents. It involves the administration by persons without any training in medicine or psychology of quasi-psychological treatment, which is harmful medically, morally and socially.''Report...'' p. 161
In Victoria this inquiry led to a ban and was legislated in the ''Psychological Practices Act, 1965'', which prohibited using an [[E-meter]] or teaching Scientology for fee or reward. In the understanding that Scientology was a form of [[psychology]]{{Citation needed|date=March 2008}}, this law required anyone practising psychology to register with the newly established Victorian Psychological Council. However, it exempted any religious denomination recognised by the Australian government under the federal Marriage Act since it used a definition of psychology broad enough to include the [[counseling|counselling]] traditionally done by [[priest]]s and [[minister (Christianity)|minister]]s of religion. Although similar laws were later passed in [[Western Australia]] in 1968 (the ''Scientology Act'') and [[South Australia]] (the ''Scientology (Prohibition) Act, 1968'' replaced by the ''Psychological Practices Act, 1973''), the Church remained active in these two States. In January 1973, the newly elected federal [[Australian Labor Party|Labor]] government recognised the Church of Scientology as a religious denomination under the Marriage Act, making it effectively exempt from the provisions of the Victorian ''Psychological Practices Act''. Western Australia had already repealed its ''Scientology Act'' in the previous year. On 25 February 1981, officials of Scientology urged repeal of the Victorian ''Psychological Practices Act'', which was subsequently amended by the ''Psychologists Registration (Scientology) Act, 1982'' to remove all references to Scientology.{{cite news |title=Scientology makes its move for an 'all-clear' |first=Wayne |last=Crawford |work=The Mercury |location=Hobart |date=2 August 1982 |page=7}} This Act was repealed by the ''Psychologists Registration Act, 1987''.{{cite web|url=http://www.legislation.vic.gov.au/Domino/Web_Notes/LDMS/LTObject_Store/LTObjSt3.nsf/DDE300B846EED9C7CA257616000A3571/06983AF6FF41C44DCA2577610028D627/$FILE/87-60a011.pdf |title=Psychologists Registration Act 1987 (Version No. 011) |date=19 May 1997 |publisher=The Parliament of Victoria |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140426155213/http://www.legislation.vic.gov.au/Domino/Web_Notes/LDMS/LTObject_Store/LTObjSt3.nsf/DDE300B846EED9C7CA257616000A3571/06983AF6FF41C44DCA2577610028D627/%24FILE/87-60a011.pdf |archivedate=26 April 2014 |deadurl=no |df= }} The South Australian ''Psychological Practices Act'' has remained in force and has a necessary role in regulating the activities of [[psychology|psychologist]]s and [[hypnotist]]s in that State. However, neither this Act itself{{cite web | url=http://www.legislation.sa.gov.au/LZ/C/A/PSYCHOLOGICAL%20PRACTICES%20ACT%201973/2010.06.30/1974.37.UN.PDF |title=Psychological Practices Act 1973 |publisher=South Australia |date=1 July 2010 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110318205446/http://www.legislation.sa.gov.au/LZ/C/A/PSYCHOLOGICAL%20PRACTICES%20ACT%201973/2010.06.30/1974.37.UN.PDF |archivedate=18 March 2011 |deadurl=no}} nor the current regulations{{cite web | url=http://www.legislation.sa.gov.au/LZ/C/R/PSYCHOLOGICAL%20PRACTICES%20REGULATIONS%201996/2003.06.11/1996.199.PDF |title=Psychological Practices Regulations 1996 |publisher=South Australia |date=1 July 2010 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110320143701/http://www.legislation.sa.gov.au/LZ/C/R/PSYCHOLOGICAL%20PRACTICES%20REGULATIONS%201996/2003.06.11/1996.199.PDF |archivedate=20 March 2011 |deadurl=no}} now contain any reference to Scientology. The Western Australian ''Scientology Act, 1968'' was repealed in 1972, and replaced by a ''Psychologists Registration Act, 1976''.{{cite web|url=http://www.slp.wa.gov.au/pco/prod/FileStore.nsf/Documents/MRDocument:18601P/$FILE/PsychologistsRegtnAct1976_01-00-00.pdf |title=Psychologists Registration Act 1976 |publisher=Western Australia |date= |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140426162114/http://www.slp.wa.gov.au/pco/prod/FileStore.nsf/Documents/MRDocument%3A18601P/%24FILE/PsychologistsRegtnAct1976_01-00-00.pdf |archivedate=26 April 2014 |deadurl=no |df= }} with similar provisions to regulate psychologists. ===1983 Victorian Supreme Court=== In 1983, the matter went to the Courts in the State of Victoria and subsequently to the [[High Court of Australia]]. Scientologists argued a $70 payroll tax should not be paid due to its status as a religious organisation. The Commissioner of Pay-Roll Tax in Victoria had ruled that Scientology was not a religion. This decision was upheld in the Supreme Court of Victoria (Judge: Crockett,J) and then on appeal in the Full Court. The judgement concluding Scientology was not a religion relied on the premise that Scientology was a philosophy rather than a religion and that the trappings of religion had only been acquired after its establishment in order to give the organisation the semblance of a religion. Some support of this position was found in Scientologist writings: Scientology's predecessor in Australia was the Hubbard Association of Scientologist International ("H.A.S.I."), This association had published, at some time not earlier than 1961, a magazine which unequivocally asserted "H.A.S.I. is '''non-religious''' -it does not demand any belief or faith nor is it in conflict with faith. People of all faiths use Scientology." The full bench of the Victorian Supreme Court affirmed that the
"Introduction of a service, ceremonies and other external indicia of a religion is no more than a cynical desire to present Scientology as what it is not for such mundane purposes as acquiring the protection of constitutional guarantees of freedom of religion or obtaining exemption from the burden of taxing laws... The creed and services described in a 1959 booklet called ''Ceremonies of The Founding Church of Scientology'' which had been published in America played absolutely no part in the teaching or practice of Scientology until the late nineteen sixties; These so-called ceremonies were devised and published as a device to enable, with such attendant advantages as would thereby accrue, Scientology to be paraded as a church in the United States and should properly be described as a masquerade and a charade."{{cite AustLII|VicRp|10|1983|litigants=Church of the New Faith v Commissioner of Pay-roll Tax (Vic) |parallelcite=[1983] 1 [[Victorian Reports|VR]] 97 |date=5 May 19823 |courtname=[[Supreme Court of Victoria|Supreme Court]] (Vic)}}.
Thus the Victorian court found that a considerable transformation had ostensibly occurred. The court found that "the ecclesiastical appearance now assumed by the organization is no more than colourable in order to serve an ulterior purpose", namely, the purpose of acquiring the legal status of a religion so that the organization might have the fiscal and other benefits of that status in Australia and elsewhere and the purpose of avoiding the legal disabilities to which the organization was subject by reason of the Psychological Practices Act 1965 (Vict.). He expressed his clear conviction that the purported transformation of Scientology to a religion was
"No more than a sham, the proclaimed belief in the efficacy of prayer is bogus, and the adoption of the paraphernalia and ceremonies of conventional religion is a mockery. The very adroitness – and alacrity – with which the tenets or structure were from time (to time) so cynically adapted to meet a deficiency thought to operate in detraction of the claim to classification as a religion serve to rob the movement of that sincerity and integrity that must be cardinal features of any religious faith."
Though the court found that at least some parts of Mr. Hubbard's writing contained merely pretended doctrines and practices of Scientology, he also found that members of the Scientology movement are "expected to and, apostates excepted, accord blind reverence to the written works of Mr. Hubbard. Although the sincerity and integrity of the ordinary members of the Scientology movement are not in doubt, Scientology is no less a sham because there are others prepared to accept and act upon such aims and beliefs as though they were credible when they can not see them for what they are. Gullibility cannot convert something from what it is to something which it is not".Victorian Supreme Court Judgement (1983) 1 VR, at p 111 (at p141) ===1983 High Court Appeal=== All these judgements were subsequently overturned by the Scientologist's appeal to the [[High Court of Australia]] in 1983, in ''[[Church of the New Faith]] v. Commissioner Of Pay-roll Tax''. The court ruled that the government of Victoria could not deny the Church the right to operate in Victoria under the legal status of "religion" for purposes of payroll taxes. All three judges in the case found that the Church of the New Faith (Church of Scientology) was a religion. Justices Mason and Brennan said: {{quote|Charlatanism is a necessary price of religious freedom, and if a self-proclaimed teacher persuades others to believe in a religion which he propounds, lack of sincerity or integrity on his part is not incompatible with the religious character of the beliefs, practices and observances accepted by his followers.}} but that: {{quote|The question to which the evidence was directed was not whether the beliefs, practices and observances of the persons in ultimate command of the organization constituted a religion but whether those of the general group of adherents constituted a religion. The question which the parties resolved to litigate must be taken to be whether the beliefs, practices and observances which the general group of adherents accept is a religion.}} Justice Murphy said: {{quote|Conclusion. The applicant has easily discharged the onus of showing that it is religious. The conclusion that it is a religious institution entitled to the tax exemption is irresistible.}} and {{quote|The conclusion to which we have ultimately come is that Scientology is, for relevant purposes, a religion. With due respect to Crockett J. and the members of the Full Supreme Court who reached a contrary conclusion, it seems to us that there are elements and characteristics of Scientology in Australia, as disclosed by the evidence, which cannot be denied.{{cite AustLII|HCA|40|1983|litigants=Church of the New Faith v Commissioner of Pay-roll Tax (Victoria) |parallelcite=(1983) 154 [[Commonwealth Law Reports|CLR]] 120 |date=27 October 1983 |courtname=[[High Court of Australia|High Court]]}}.}} Wilson and Deane said: {{quote|Regardless of whether the members of the applicant are gullible or misled or whether the practices of Scientology are harmful or objectionable, the evidence, in our view, establishes that Scientology must, for relevant purposes, be accepted as "a religion" in Victoria. That does not, of course, mean either that the practices of the applicant or its rules are beyond the control of the law of the State or that the applicant or its members are beyond its taxing powers.}} The High Court of Australia restored Scientology's tax exempt status in 1983. The High Court's decision, dismissing the earlier judgements, now serves as the current precedent for defining religious groups.{{cite web |url=http://www.cdi.gov.au/report/cdi_chap20.htm |title=Australian Charities Definition Inquiry, Chapter 20: The Advancement of Religion |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140124215052/http://cdi.gov.au/report/cdi_chap20.htm |archivedate=24 January 2014 |deadurl=yes |df=dmy-all }} As part of the court’s judgment, according to scholar James Richardson: “the Court went on to state that a religion did not have to be theistic, and that a religion involved both belief and behavior, thus avoiding crude dichotomy promulgated by the famous polygamy case in America in 1897. The case is still the leading case in Australia defining religion, and is cited in other courts and countries as well.”{{cite journal |title=Scientology: Sect, Science, or Scam? |journal=Numen |year=2015 |last=Lewis |first=James R. |volume=62 |issue=2 |pages=226-242 }} == Controversies == === Revesby murder === Linda Walicki, who was diagnosed with a psychiatric illness, was not administered psychiatric drugs prescribed by the hospital because of the beliefs of her Scientologist parents.{{cite news| last=Braithwaithe | first=David| title =Scientology cited in killings | work = The Sidney Morning Herald | date = 10 July 2007 | url=http://www.smh.com.au/news/national/scientology-denied-daughter-help/2007/07/09/1183833431861.html?page=fullpage| accessdate =28 May 2010 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101130081155/http://www.smh.com.au/news/national/scientology-denied-daughter-help/2007/07/09/1183833431861.html?page=fullpage |archivedate=30 November 2010 |deadurl=no}} Instead her parents administered vitamins imported from the United States. Her condition worsened, and her parents became alarmed, finally relenting and administering the prescribed medicine. However, three weeks later, she assaulted them, killing her father Michael and sister Kathryn, and wounding her mother Sue.{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2007/jul/10/australia.mainsection |author=Macmhon, Barbara |title=Accused family killer was 'denied treatment by Scientologist parents' |work=The Guardian |date=10 July 2007 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140426171627/http://www.theguardian.com/world/2007/jul/10/australia.mainsection |archivedate=26 April 2014 |deadurl=no}} The mother has since recovered.{{cite news |url=http://www.smh.com.au/news/National/Mum-stabbed-by-own-kid-out-of-hospital/2007/07/19/1184559932766.html |title=Mum 'stabbed by own kid' out of hospital |date=19 July 2007 | work = The Sidney Morning Herald |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140426173723/http://www.smh.com.au/news/National/Mum-stabbed-by-own-kid-out-of-hospital/2007/07/19/1184559932766.html |archivedate=26 April 2014 |deadurl=no}} After the incident, Australian Church of Scientology vice-president Cyrus Brooks in Sydney continued to criticise Psychiatry and Psychiatric drugs, while the Australian Medical Association President Dr Rosanna Capolingua, speaking on ABC Radio, said if "the girl had had access to appropriate medical treatment it could have changed the course of her life."{{cite news| url=http://www.smh.com.au/articles/2007/07/10/1183833476294.html | author=Welsh, Dylan |work=The Sydney Morning Herald | title=Scientologists 'flat earthers' | date=10 July 2007 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070713062941/http://www.smh.com.au/articles/2007/07/10/1183833476294.html |archivedate=13 July 2007 |deadurl=no}} Linda has since been found not guilty by reason of insanity and has been taken to a hospital for further treatment.{{cite web |url=http://www.lawlink.nsw.gov.au/scjudgments/2008nswsc.nsf/6ccf7431c546464bca2570e6001a45d2/19f632af45ea51f1ca2574950013fe2f |title=R v Walicki [2008] NSWSC 777 |publisher=New South Wales Supreme Court |date=30 July 2008 }} === Queen Street massacre === {{Main|Queen Street massacre}} In the [[Queen Street massacre]] case, the gunman, Frank Vitkovic, had been tested by the Church of Scientology two months before he shot a number of people in the Queen Street Massacre.{{cite news |author=Pitt, Helen |title=Court sees Video of Queen st Shootings |work=Sydney Morning Herald |date=16 September 1988}}{{cite news |title=No rest for the Wicked |work=The Age|date=30 November 1997 |page=1}} "Vitkovic took a personality test carried out by a Church of Scientology volunteer. The results of the test, the Scientology volunteer believed, made her suspect that he might have hit rock bottom. The voluntary worker, Ms Eleanor Simpson, who had no formal training in psychology, believed Vitkovic was extremely depressed. She could recall only one other personality test having a worse result. She did not refer Vitkovic to a psychiatrist but suggested he enrol in the Ups and Downs in Life course run by the Church."{{cite news |author=Pitt, Helen |title=Inside the mind of a mass murderer |work=Sydney Morning Herald |date=8 October 1988}} Forensic psychiatrist Dr Alan Bartholomew presented evidence at the Inquest concerning Scientology's testing of gunman [[Frank Vitkovic]]. Bartholomew indicated that the Scientologist's testing of the gunman [[Frank Vitkovic]], though revealing that Vitkovic was suffering a serious mental condition, did not result in his being treated effectively. Bartholomew also stated that the test itself may have contributed to Vitkovic's mental state before he shot eight people in 1988.{{cite news |author=Hall, J. |title=Queen St.Church to blame |work=Herald |date=4 October 1988}} While repeating some of these comments the Coroner said in his findings "there is no evidence that Vitkovic was influenced by his being provided with the written results of a Scientology Personality Test".Hallenstein, 5346/87 20 October 1988 The Coroner also noted the day before coming into the Church of Scientology Vitkovic was prescribed "appropriate medication" for stress related headaches and hypertension. An alternative interpretation of events is provided by the Director of the Australian Institute of Criminology Adam Graycar: {{blockquote|In his diary, Vitkovic also confided this advice "Look for people with a history of rejection, loneliness and ill treatment who also have a fascination with guns and you won’t go wrong". The inquest exposed the tortured mind of a young man who saw himself as a failure, inadequate and lonely, tormented by violent fantasies and finally suffused with hatred. He sought refuge in erotic and violent books and videos and cultivated a morbid interest in firearms."{{cite web |url=http://www.aic.gov.au/media_library/conferences/other/graycar_adam/2003-04-sig.pdf |title=Violence in the Workplace: Personal and Political Issues presented at the 2003 Security in Government Conference|author=Adam Graycar |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140212091917/http://www.aic.gov.au/media_library/conferences/other/graycar_adam/2003-04-sig.pdf |archivedate=12 February 2014 |deadurl=no}}}} === Speech by Senator Xenophon === {{Further|Aaron Saxton}} [[File:2009 07 24 Nick Xenophon speaking cropped.jpg|thumb|upright=0.56|[[Senate of Australia|Senator]] [[Nick Xenophon]] in 2009]] In November 2009 Independent [[Senate of Australia|Senator]] [[Nick Xenophon]] spoke in the parliament{{cite hansard |jurisdiction=Commonwealth of Australia |house=Senate |title=Church of Scientology |url=http://parlinfo.aph.gov.au/parlInfo/search/display/display.w3p;query=Id%3A%22chamber%2Fhansards%2F2009-11-17%2F0217%22 |date=November 17, 2009 |page=8073 |speaker=Nick Xenophon |position=Senator}} about the organisation, describing it as a "criminal organisation" and saying that he had letters from former followers which included "claims of abuse, false imprisonment and forced abortion."{{cite news|url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/stories/2009/11/18/2745765.htm|work=ABC News|date=18 November 2009|title=Scientology a 'criminal organisation' |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120211081223/http://www.abc.net.au/news/2009-11-18/scientology-a-criminal-organisation/1146494 |archivedate=11 February 2012 |deadurl=no}} His staff interviewed a number of people who made the claims. They were a member of the World Institute of Scientology Enterprises and they sold tools based on The Hubbard Management Business System [HMBS]. == Litigation == The Church of Scientology has been involved in a number of lawsuits and threatened legal action during its five decade history in Australia. * A suit was brought against [[Kevin Victor Anderson|Anderson]] and his assistant Gordon Just who produced the [[Anderson Report]], in 1971. The citations in the Victorian Reports are: Hubbard Association of Scientologists -v- Anderson (1971) VR 788; Hubbard Association of Scientologists v. Anderson (1972) VR 340 [appeal of 1971 VR 740]; Hubbard Association of Scientologists International v Anderson and Just (No 2) (1972) VR 577. The Victorian Parliament passed special legislation to give the two immunity from these writs.{{cite book |author=Anderson, Kevin |date=1986 |title=Fossil In The Sandstone: The Recollecting Judge |publisher=Spectrum Publications |location=Melbourne. |isbn=0-86786-095-2}} * The Church of Scientology requested a tax exemption from wages originating from a religious institution based on the Victoria Pay-roll Tax Act 1971. The High Court asked the question on whether Scientology was to be accepted as a religion, and decided that they were. Scientology met the two criteria that they stipulated for the determination of whether an organization is religious; first “belief in a supernatural Being, Thing or Principle” and second, “the acceptance of canons of conduct in order to give effect to that belief.”{{cite conference |last=Carobene |first=Germana |title=Acta Comparanda |language=English, French |url=http://www.observatoire-religion.com/2016/12/scientology-in-a-scholarly-perspective/ |booktitle=The research of a juridical identity for Scientology, according to recent European case law |conference=International Conference – Scientology in a scholarly perspective 24-25th January 2014 |publisher=University of Antwerp, Faculty for Comparative Study of Religions and Humanism |place=Antwerp, Belgium |year=2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170216050903/http://www.observatoire-religion.com/2016/12/scientology-in-a-scholarly-perspective/ |archivedate=16 February 2017 |df=dmy-all }} * Scientology also litigated against the [[Australian Security Intelligence Organisation]], which is Australia's domestic intelligence service.{{cite AustLII|HCA|38|1982|litigants=Church of Scientology v Woodward |parallelcite=(1982) 154 [[Commonwealth Law Reports|CLR]] 25 |date=19 November 1982 |courtname=[[High Court of Australia|High Court]]}}. ==Billboard promotion== Scientology used a notable promotion in Sydney for many years, an "electronic talking billboard" a 33 metre high Volcano billboard situated in the main cinema district on George Street. It is internally illuminated by 150 special display lamps synchronised to create a stylised simulation of lava flowing down the sides of the volcano. Each eruption heralds the screening of ads on the TV screen. Non-toxic smoke will spew from the crater at regular intervals." The billboard was used to promote Dianetics books.{{cite news |first=Andrew |last=Hornery |work=Sydney Morning Herald |date= 4 May 1996 |page=13 |title=Scientologists' message goes up in hi-tech {{Infobox artwork | image = [[Image:Sultanganj-budda.jpg|right|300px]] | title = Sultanganj Buddha | movement = [[Gupta-Pala transitional period]] | year = 500-700 AD | material = [[Copper]] | city = [[Birmingham]] | museum = [[Birmingham Museum & Art Gallery]] | height_metric = 2.3 | width_metric = 1 | metric_unit = m | italic title=no }}
The '''Sultanganj Buddha''' is a [[Gupta Empire|Gupta]]-[[Pala Empire|Pala]] transitional period sculpture, the largest substantially complete copper Buddha figure known from the time. The statue is dated by archaeologists to between 500 and 700 AD. It is 2.3 m high and 1 m wide and weighs over 500 kg. It was found in the [[North India]]n town of [[Sultanganj]], [[Bhagalpur district]], [[Bihar]]<ref>http://www.bbc.co.uk/birmingham/content/articles/2006/05/10/sultanganj_buddha_feature.shtml</ref> in 1861 during the construction of the [[East Indian Railway]].<ref name="Wingfield">Wingfield, Christopher (2010) Touching the Buddha: Encounters with a charismatic object. In Museum Materialities: Objects, Engagements, Interpretations, ed. Sandra H. Dudley, Routledge: London & New York, pp.53-70. http://www.routledge.com/books/details/9780415492188/</ref> It is now held by [[Birmingham Museum and Art Gallery]], [[Birmingham]], [[England]].
==Description== The Sultanganj Buddha was cast in pure, unrefined copper by the ''cire perdue'', or [[list-wax casting|lost wax]], technique. It stands with his right hand raised in ''[[abhayamudra]]'' (a gesture of reassurance or protection), and his left hand is held downwards with palm outwards, said to indicate granting a favour. The end of the monastic robe is held between the thumb and forefinger of this hand in the manner that is still practised by [[Theravada|Theravadin]] monks.
==Discovery and later history== [[File:Sultanganj Buddha found.jpg|thumb|EB Harris with the Sultanganj Buddha. 1861/1862]] [[File:Sultanganj Buddha.JPG|thumb|right|250px|Stone statue of Buddha from Sultanganj in the [[British Museum]] Lotus petals inscribed with "[[Ye Dharma Hetu]]" mantra]] E. B. Harris, the railway engineer who discovered the Buddha during excavations that he carried out on ancient remains near the Sultanganj station that he was constructing, published a detailed account of his work, complete with a site plan and photographs. He describes finding the right foot of the Buddha ten feet under the surface, beneath a floor he considered to have been used to conceal the statue after it had been toppled from its former place.<ref>Harris, E. B. (1864) Description of Buddhist Remains Discovered at Sooltangunge, London: privately published.</ref> Harris sent the statue to Birmingham, the cost of its transport to England being paid by Samuel Thornton, a Birmingham manufacturer of ironmongery. Thornton, himself a former mayor of Birmingham, offered it to the [[Birmingham City Council|Borough Council]] for their proposed Art Museum in 1864. In Birmingham, a town that boasted a thousand trades, the Art Museum was intended to be an exemplar and inspiration for local metalworkers and other artisans.
Over the years, it has been shown in a number of prominent locations throughout [[Birmingham Museum and Art Gallery]] (BMAG) and remains an indispensable display item. It was the foundation donation to the collections and is BMAG's most treasured possession.<ref>http://www.bmagic.org.uk/objects/1885A1116</ref> Harris's report shows him with the Buddha and a number of smaller finds. They included two much smaller standing Buddhas in stone: one is now in the [[British Museum]] and the other in the [[Asian Art Museum of San Francisco]]. A stone Buddha head, also from Sultanganj, is now in the [[Victoria and Albert Museum]], London.<ref>[https://www.britishmuseum.org/research/collection_online/collection_object_details.aspx?objectId=5098&partId=1&place=39987&plaA=39987-2-11&page=1 British Museum Collection]</ref><ref>[http://searchcollection.asianart.org/view/objects/asitem/id/19594 Asian Art Museum Collection]</ref><ref>[https://collections.vam.ac.uk/item/O64237/head-of-the-buddha-sculpture-unknown/ Victoria and Albert Museum Collection]</ref>
==Current location== From 1998 to 2015, the Buddha was the centrepiece of a gallery at Birmingham Museum and Art Gallery dedicated to displaying a number of Buddhas and related artefacts, and Birmingham Museum held an annual 'Buddha Day', when West Midlands-based Buddhist groups from a range of traditions would bless the statue.
During 2015, Birmingham Museum and Art Gallery worked with representatives of a number of faith groups from the city on the creation of a new 'Faith Gallery', and the Sultanganj Buddha was moved from its previous location. It is now displayed in a new gallery that tells the story of the range of faiths that are practiced in Birmingham.
==See also== * [[Brahma from Mirpur-Khas]]
==Gallery== <gallery> Image:Sultanganj_budda1.jpg|Abhaymudra of Sultanganj Buddha </gallery>

{{Infobox Egyptian dignitary | Name= Tefibi (Itj-ibj) | Style = Nomarch
of the 13th ''nomos'' of Upper Egypt | Image = Tomb Tefibi Mariette.jpg | Image_size = 220px | Caption= Drawing of a wall of Tefibi's tomb | Predecessor= [[Khety I (nomarch)|Khety I]] | Successor= [[Khety II (nomarch)|Khety II]] | Dynasty= [[Tenth Dynasty of Egypt|10th Dynasty]] | Pharaoh= [[Wahkare Khety]] and [[Merykare]] | Father= Khety I | Mother= | Wife= | Children= Khety II | Burial= [[Asyut]], tomb III }} '''Tefibi''' (or '''Itj-ibj''' – ''It(.i)ib(.i)''Donald B. Spanel, in [[Donald B. Redford]] (ed), ''The Oxford Encyclopedia of Ancient Egypt'' vol. 1, Oxford University Press, 2001, pp. 154-6. – in a more modern reading) was an [[ancient Egypt]]ian [[nomarch]] of the 13th ''[[Nome (Egypt)|nomos]]'' of [[Upper Egypt]] (''"the Upper [[Ficus sycomorus|Sycamore]]"'') during the [[Tenth Dynasty of Egypt|10th Dynasty]] (c. 21st century BCE, during the [[First Intermediate Period]]). In addition, he also was ''hereditary prince, count, wearer of the royal seal, sole companion'' and ''high priest of [[Wepwawet]]''. The main source about his life came from his biography, inscribed on the "tomb III" in [[Asyut]].[[James Henry Breasted]], ''Ancient Records of Egypt'', vol 1, 1907, The University of Chicago Press, § 391 ff. It is generally assumed that Tefibi was the second of a trio of related nomarchs datable to the [[Heracleopolis Magna|Herakleopolite]] period; he was likely preceded by his father Khety and followed by his son, also named [[Khety II (nomarch)|Khety]]. ==Biography== He was member of a long line of nomarchs in Asyut with strong bonds of loyalty and friendship towards the [[Heracleopolis Magna|Herakleopolite]] dynasty, and seems that he continued the policy of good governance pursued by his father [[Khety I (nomarch)|Khety I]]: in fact, Tefibi praised the safety and the respect of the laws in his ''nomos''.[[William C. Hayes]], in ''[[The Cambridge Ancient History]]'', vol 1, part 2, 1971 (2008), Cambridge University Press, {{ISBN|0-521-077915}}, p. 469.
When [[11th Dynasty of Egypt|the Thebans]] extended their influences on [[Thinis]] and [[Abydos, Egypt|Abydos]], the Herakleopolite [[pharaoh]] (who is generally believed to be [[Wahkare Khety]]) and Tefibi rallied their troops, and swiftly regained Thinis. Their undisciplined soldiers sacked the sacred [[necropolis]], as reported by the king himself in the ''[[Teaching for King Merykare]]''.Hayes, op. cit., p. 466-467. Tefibi died during the reign of king [[Merykare]], who installed [[Khety II (nomarch)|Khety II]], son of the deceased, as nomarch in Asyut. ==References== {{Reflist}} ==Further reading== * Spanel, Donald B., "The Herakleopolitan Tombs of Kheti I, Jt(.j)jb(.j), and Kheti II at Asyut", ''Orientalia'', 58, 1989, pp. 301–14. ==External links== * [http://www.reshafim.org.il/ad/egypt/texts/tefibi.htm The Biography of Tefibi] {{authority control}} [[Category:Nomarchs]] [[Category:People of the Tenth Dynasty of Egypt]] [[Category:Ancient Egyptian priests]] [[Category:Ancient Egyptian Royal Seal-bearer]]

[[Buddhism|Buddhist democracy]] | position = [[Left-wing]] to [[Right-wing]] | international = | european = | europarl = | seats1_title = | seats1 = | seats2_title = | seats2 = | seats3_title = | seats3 = | colours = | website = | country = Cambodia }} The '''Union of Cambodian Democrats''' was a political alliance in [[Cambodia]], which was formed by three political parties, one of them being the Khmer Nation Party of [[Sam Rainsy]], Prince [[Norodom Ranariddh]] was involved as well. These three political parties called their umbrella group the "Union of Cambodian Democrats".{{cite news|url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9F0DE0DE153AF93BA1575AC0A961958260|title=Cambodian Leaders in Exile Seek International Monitoring of New Elections|author=Crossette, Barbara|publisher=The New York Times|date=September 28, 1997}} It was created in exile in 1997 after a [[coup d'etat]].{{cite web|url=http://my.cambodia.org/profile/kem_sokha|title=Kem Sokha's Page|publisher=Cambodian Information Center}} The leaders of three political parties which united their leadership and political parties together to create the Union of Cambodian Democrats were Sam Rainsy's [[Sam Rainsy Party]], [[Son Sann]]'s [[Buddhist Liberal Democratic Party]] (now led by [[Son Soubert]]) and also prince [[Norodom Ranariddh]]'s [[FUNCINPEC]] party. However, from the late 90's onwards a new political party,the [[Bou Hel]] and [[Ty Chhin]]'s [[Khmer Neutral Party]], became part of the alliance .{{cite news| url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9F0DE0DE153AF93BA1575AC0A961958260 | work=The New York Times | title=Cambodian Leaders in Exile Seek International Monitoring of New Elections | first=Barbara | last=Crossette | date=September 28, 1997 | accessdate=May 26, 2010}} {{cite news| url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9C03E0DB1638F931A15751C1A9669C8B63&partner=rssnyt&emc=rss | work=The New York Times | title=Son Sann, 89, Strong Nationalist For Cambodia for Six Decades | date=December 22, 2000}}{{cite web|url=http://necelect.org.kh/English/politicalReg/2003/content_2002-2003.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=October 14, 2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080908221601/http://www.necelect.org.kh/English/politicalReg/2003/content_2002-2003.html |archivedate=September 8, 2008 }}[https://web.archive.org/web/*/http://www.datagraphic.fr/ucd/] Its goals are democracy, peace and sovereignty of what they consider as being the territories of Cambodia. ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *[https://web.archive.org/web/19990202153854/http://www.datagraphic.fr/ucd/ Former Union of Cambodian Democrats website] at archive.org {{Cambodian political parties}} [[Category:Cambodian democracy movements]] [[Category:Political party alliances in Cambodia]] [[Category:Buddhist political parties]] {{Cambodia-stub}}

The '''Universal Torah Registry''' is a project of the [[Jewish Community Relations Council|JCRC]] (Jewish Community Relations Council) of [[New York City]], originally established in 1982, designed to protect and secure [[Sefer Torah|Torah scrolls]] of [[Jews|Jewish communities]], from theft. As these scrolls may be valued at between $5,000 to $20,000, and could fetch similar amounts on the [[black market]], [[synagogue]]s have been a target of thieves.
The UTR currently has approximately 1000 subscribing synagogues nationwide. Some synagogues and Jewish communities are not aware of this program, and in some communities, religious leaders refuse to endorse the program.
== External links == * [https://web.archive.org/web/20060212040324/http://www.wired.com/news/culture/0,1284,67743,00.html?tw=wn_story_page_prev2 News story on the security issues] * [http://jcrcny.org/utr/ Universal Torah Registry]

'''Yum Kaax''' (Mayan pronunciation: [jum kaːʃ], 'Lord of the forest') is a [[Yukatek Maya]] name for the god of the wild vegetation and guardian of its animals.
In the past, this character has wrongly been described as an agricultural deity, or even as the Maya maize god (god E of the codices),<ref>Steele 1977: 1062</ref> which has become a popular and still existing misconception.<ref>Thompson 1970: 289</ref> In ethnographic reality, Yum Kaax is a god of wild plants and of animals that are important to hunters. As such, he grants protection of the fields against the incursions of the wild nature he himself represents. <ref>Thompson 1930: 107-108, 173</ref> This type of deity is also found among indigenous peoples of North America. Invoked by hunters, he is the owner of all the game. He can appear to hunters in an instant and possesses songs that will warrant a hunter success, and allow his arrows to come back to him.
==Role in Mayan Culture== Pre-Columbian contact, Yum Kaax was considered one of the most important deities in the Maya Pantheon and was used to help those who hunted for their food. Tradition farmers would invoke his name and present him with the first fruits of their fields, carved out from the forest<ref>cf. Thompson 1930: 107-108, 173</ref> so that wild animals and vegetation would not destroy their fields. Hunters far out in the wilderness would sometimes take off their shirt, spread it over four stakes in the ground and then crawl underneath to try and find deer. This is a ritual to Yum Kaax so that deer become easier to find. <ref>Muntsch 1943: 34</ref>
==Mayan beliefs from Yum Kaax== Mayan Sorcerers have learned many secrets from Yum Kaax, and these would be used to help one get better results while hunting. some of the advice given was: When you go hunting, you must first offer Yum Kaax 5 jars of [[Balché]] or nine of chocozacan. To find game, create a candle of [[Copal]] and follow the flicker of the flame. To select your own private hunting ground, kill a deer and cut off its head and then drag the head around the hunting ground and bury the head with its liver – the area that you have dragged the head over will become your own private hunting ground. <ref>Muntsch 1943: 34</ref> ==Notes== {{reflist}}
==References== *Thompson, J.E.S., '' Ethnology of the Mayas of southern and central British Honduras''. Chicago 1930. *Thompson, J.E.S., ''Maya History and Religion''. Norman: U. of Oklahoma Press 1970. *Steele, R.L., "Dying, Death, and Bereavement Among the Maya Indians of Mesoamerica A Study in Anthropological Psychology". American Psychologist 1977. *Thompson, J.E.S., "The Civilization of the Mayas". Field Museum of Natural History 1927. *Spence, L., "The Gods of the Maya". The Open Court 1926. *Muntsch, A., "Some Magico-Religious Observances of the Present-Day Maya Indians of British Honduras and Yucatan". The George Washington University Institute for Ethnographic Research 1943.
